quiz.title: Unit 12: AP Microeconomics (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: Market Equilibrium, Government Intervention & Elasticity
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Equilibrium Analysis, Price Floors/Ceilings, Elasticity Applications

questions.question: An increase (rightward shift) in the demand for a good will tend to cause
options: an increase in the equilibrium price and quantity.
none of these answers.
an increase in the equilibrium price and a decrease in the equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in the equilibrium price and an increase in the equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in the equilibrium price and quantity.
questions.explanation: Increased demand shifts the demand curve rightward, leading to higher equilibrium price and quantity.

questions.question: If the price of a good is equal to the equilibrium price,
options: there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will fall.
the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied and the price remains unchanged.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will rise.
there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will rise.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will fall.
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, Qd = Qs, no shortage or surplus, so price is stable.

questions.question: If the price of a good is below the equilibrium price,
options: there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will rise.
the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied and the price remains unchanged.
there is a shortage (i.e. an excess demand) and the price will fall.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will rise.
there is a surplus (i.e. an excess supply) and the price will fall.
questions.explanation: Below equilibrium, Qd > Qs (shortage). Competition among buyers drives price upward toward equilibrium.

questions.question: Johnny is currently spending his entire weekly snack budget on 5 bags of candy and 4 juice boxes. At his current level of consumption, Johnny's marginal utility for candy is 5 utils and his marginal utility for juice boxes is 10 utils. In order to maximize his total utility, Johnny should
options: maintain his current level of consumption of candy and juice boxes regardless of the prices
consume more candy and fewer juice boxes regardless of the prices
consume more juice boxes and fewer candy regardless of the prices
maintain his current level of consumption if the price of candy is $2 and the price of a juice box is $1
maintain his current level of consumption if the price of candy is $1 and the price of a juice box is $2
questions.explanation: Utility maximization requires MUc / Pc = MUj / Pj. With MUc = 5 and MUj = 10, this holds if Pc = $1 and Pj = $2: 5/1 = 10/2 = 5.

questions.question: A firm experiencing diseconomies of scale will have
options: a long-run supply curve that is horizontal.
a long-run marginal cost curve that decreases as output increases.
a long-run total cost that decreases as output increases.
a long-run average total cost that increases as output increases.
a long-run average total cost that decreases as output increases.
questions.explanation: Diseconomies of scale: LRATC increases as output expands due to coordination/management problems.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a perfectly competitive market?
options: a market structure with a large number of interdependent large firms selling identical products
a market structure with dozens of small firms offering a differentiated product with easy entry into the market
a market that is productively efficient, but not allocatively efficient
a market that has high barriers to entry
a market structure where individual firms have no control over the price that they charge
questions.explanation: In perfect competition, firms are price takers â€” they have no control over market price.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the marginal revenue curve as a single-price monopolist increases its output in the short run?
options: decreasing at first, then increasing
increasing at first, then decreasing
horizontal and equal to the market price
decreasing and equal to the monopolist's demand curve
decreasing and below the monopolist's demand curve
questions.explanation: For a downward-sloping demand curve, MR is also downward sloping and lies below demand because to sell more, the monopolist must lower price on all units.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true of a monopolistically competitive firm in long-run equilibrium?
options: Price equals average total cost and marginal cost
Price equals average total cost but is greater than marginal cost.
Marginal cost equals marginal revenue
The firm uses product differentiation.
The firm earns a normal profit
questions.explanation: In monopolistic competition, P = ATC (zero economic profit), but P > MC (since demand slopes down and MR < P). So (A) is false because P does not equal MC.

questions.question: Which of the following must be true for a firm that is a natural monopoly?
options: It can produce and supply its product to an entire market at a lower cost than could a number of smaller firms.
It produces at the minimum of its average total cost curve.
It has a patent on its product.
It will not be able to maximize profits unless subsidized by the government.
It is productively efficient for the government to break up the monopoly into smaller firms.
questions.explanation: A natural monopoly exists due to economies of scale over the entire relevant market output. One large firm can produce at a lower per-unit cost than several smaller firms could.

questions.question: In the short run, if a firm produces the level of output at which marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost but price is less than average total cost, the firm will
options: always shut down production
expand output to lower its average fixed cost
continue to operate if price is greater than its average variable cost
decrease output until price equals its average total cost
increase output to increase revenue
questions.explanation: The short-run shutdown rule: A firm minimizes losses by continuing to produce if P > AVC, as it can cover variable costs and some fixed costs. MR=MC is the profit-maximizing (or loss-minimizing) output rule.

questions.question: Assume that a firm uses only one variable input. If a firm is experiencing diminishing returns, which of the following is true as more of the variable input is used?
options: Marginal cost will decrease at a constant rate.
Marginal cost will decrease at a diminishing rate.
Marginal cost will increase.
Marginal product will increase at a constant rate.
Marginal product will increase at a diminishing rate.
questions.explanation: Diminishing marginal returns means each additional unit of the variable input adds less to output (MP decreases). When MP falls, the cost of producing that additional output (MC) rises.

questions.question: Assuming a linear downward-sloping demand curve, as a monopoly firm sells additional units of output, its marginal revenue will
options: increase at an increasing rate
increase at first, then decrease
decrease at first, then increase
decrease continuously
remain constant
questions.explanation: With a linear, downward-sloping demand curve, the marginal revenue curve is also linear, has the same intercept, and twice the slope. It therefore decreases continuously as output increases.

questions.question: Collusion, price leadership, and price wars are usually observed in which of the following market structures?
options: Perfect competition
Monopolistic competition
Oligopoly
Monopoly
Natural monopoly
questions.explanation: Oligopoly is characterized by a small number of interdependent firms. This interdependence leads to strategic behavior, including attempts to collude (cooperate), tacit cooperation through price leadership, and competitive breakdowns like price wars.

questions.question: Which of the following breakdowns in the rules of perfect competition is likely to result in a market externality?
options: Increasing returns to scale in production
Many sellers, one buyer
Firms sell differentiated, non-identical products
High entry and exit barriers
Poorly defined property rights
questions.explanation: Externalities (spillover costs/benefits) occur when property rights are not clearly defined or enforceable. This allows costs or benefits to be imposed on third parties without compensation, a fundamental market failure not present in the perfect competition model.

questions.question: The following are characteristics of a perfectly competitive market. Among these, which is most clearly lacking in the market for used cars?
options: Factors of production are perfectly mobile in the long run
Well defined property rights
Lack of increasing returns to scale
Large number of buyers and sellers
Buyers and sellers have perfect information on the quality of the product
questions.explanation: The used car market is a classic example of a market suffering from 'asymmetric information' (the 'lemons problem'). Sellers know more about the car's true quality than buyers, which violates the perfect competition assumption of perfect information.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of equilibrium analysis and market interventions.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review price controls and elasticity applications.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding; focus on shortage/surplus dynamics and policy effects.
scoreMessages.0: Review: market equilibrium, price floors/ceilings, and elasticity calculations.
